comments.body: Yes, the Path ID is limited to a maximum value of 2^32-1 because of its usage in the none calculation, see https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#name-nonce-calculation

issues.title: Can we limit the maximum value of the path ID to 2^30-1?
issues.author: nandsky

comments.author: LPardue
comments.body:
The reality is, this is going to be dealt with like every other variable length integer and handled as a u64. Then, whatever additional limits are placed on the value will come into play. 

I don't see much benefit in trying to save 4 bytes of program space per path ID by micro optimising the wire formats.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: +1 to what @LPardue wrote. We only have a hard requirement to not use path ID larger than 2^32 -1. Yes, the encoding of the values >= 2^30 will not be very efficient. But if applications do need the extra 2 bits, encoding efficiency is not a sufficient reason to prevent them.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: @nandsky thanks for this proposal. This was already discussed in issue #307 and as also indicted by the answers above we concluded that this optimisation doesn't bring much benefit. Therefore I will close this issue as a duplicate.

issues.title: When initial_max_path_id exceeds 2^32-1, which error code should be used?
issues.author: nandsky
issues.body:
If we follow the conventions of RFC 9000, should we use TRANSPORT_PARAMETER_ERROR? If so, should we explicitly document this?

[7.4. ](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9000.html#section-7.4)[Transport Parameters](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9000.html#name-transport-parameters)

> An endpoint MUST treat receipt of a transport parameter with an invalid value as a connection error of type TRANSPORT_PARAMETER_ERROR.

By the way, would it be more appropriate to use **TRANSPORT_PARAMETER_ERROR** instead of [**TRANSPORT_PARAMETER error**](https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#section-2-11)?

> Cipher suites with a nonce shorter than 12 bytes cannot be used together with the multipath extension. If such a cipher suite is selected and the use of the multipath extension is negotiated, endpoints MUST abort the handshake with a **TRANSPORT_PARAMETER error**.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Thanks for noting this oversight! Yes we need an error here and I agree that I think TRANSPORT_PARAMETER_ERROR is the right error type. I created PR #434

issues.title: Should 0xffffffff be reserved for scenarios where no "max_path_id" is set?
issues.author: nandsky
issues.body:
In issue #425, we discussed the maximum value for max_path_id, but based on practical experience, can we retain 0xffffffff for non-multipath scenarios?

There are 4 scenarios for max_path_id negotiation:
1. Both sides have no max_path_id configured
2. Endpoint has max_path_id set, peer doesn't send it
3. Endpoint has no max_path_id set, peer sends it
4. Both sides have max_path_id set, and there's a confirmed value

as described in  [Introduction of an Explicit Path Identifier](https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#name-introduction-of-an-explicit), [0, 2^32-1] have been used by multi-path，there is no value in uint32_t to represent no "max_path_id" set (initial value), so we need a uint64_t or an extra single-bit variable. for example:
```c
   uint64_t  max_path_id_remote; /* The initial value is  0xffffffffffffffff */
   uint64_t  max_path_id_local;  /* The initial value is  0xffffffffffffffff */
   uint64_t  max_path_id;  /* The initial value is  0xffffffffffffffff */
   signed    multipath_enabled:1;  /* this variable can be replaced with the expression max_path_id == 0xffffffffffffffff */
```
but:
1. If we use uint64_t, then 0x0000000100000000 - 0xffffffffffffffffff seems meaningless and waste some memory.
2. If we use a separate signed max_path_id:1 to express it, this would introduce additional complexity and also waste a little bit of memory.

If we reserve 0xffffffff for uninitialized max_path_id, then we only need three uint32_t variables to express the 4 scenarios.
```c
   uint32_t  max_path_id_remote;  /* The initial value is  0xffffffff */
   uint32_t  max_path_id_local; /* The initial value is  0xffffffff */
   uint32_t  max_path_id; /* The initial value is  0xffffffff */
```

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: The multipath extension is indicated by the use of the initial_max_path_id transport parameter, therefore it is not possible to use the multipath extension without setting the max_path_id. The multipath_enabled transport parameter does not exist anymore and was replaced by initial_max_path_id with the introduction of the explicit path ID. If you don't want to limit the number of path IDs, you can set the initial_max_path_id transport parameter to the maximum value. See section https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#name-handshake-negotiation-and-t

issues.title: Automatic closing of unintentional duplicate paths
issues.author: tzaeschke
issues.body:
```
[..]. To avoid this pitfall, endpoints could
adopt a simple coordination rule, such as only letting the client
initiate closure of duplicate paths, or perhaps relying on
the application protocol to decide which paths should be closed.
```

I understand this as: it is okay to just implement the simple rule,
and that letting the application protocol decide is an optional feature.

This should IMHO be more prescriptive and make sure that this also works for a path-aware network, where use of multiple paths for the same 4-tuple is very intentional. 

I think the application should always be able to decide on the policy and only use the simple rule if no application protocol is defined or if it indicates that the simple rule is fine.

I would propose to change the phrasing here to something like:

```
[..]. To avoid this pitfall, endpoints should allow the application
protocol to decide whether or which path to close. If the application
protocol defines no such rule, a simple default coordination rule 
could be adopted, such as only letting the client initiate closure of 
duplicate paths.
```

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I don't think this change makes a real difference. However, note that is it also possible to deploy the multipath extension without application awareness.

comments.author: tzaeschke
comments.body:
I agree that application awareness should be optional from the point of view of application developers.
However, I think if a library supports application awareness at all, it definitely should support replacing the "simple rule" with something else.

My concern is that implementers may choose to hard code the "simple coordination rule", This would be problematic if an application with intentional duplicate path usage creates two paths with distinct 4-tuples and these two paths are then migrated to the same 4-tuple (the same example given in the text). If the "simple rule" is hard coded, this would cause one of the paths top disappear.

In other words: if an implementation supports duplicate paths _and_ supports application awareness, then it definitely _should_ support replacing the "simple rule" with something else.
One alternative is that the implementation is somehow aware that duplicate paths are desirable and in that case employs an alternative coordination rule of "don´t do anything, having duplicate paths is fine".

Does that make sense?

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: I am not sure that we should get into discussions of APIs. We do not specify an API in the draft, and I don't think that we would have enough experience to do that well. For example, it is not clear that stacks will let applications manage paths *at all* -- they could have simple policy rules to handle the path creation under the hood. I don't think we should add any text there.

comments.author: tzaeschke
comments.body:
> I am not sure that we should get into discussions of APIs. 

I'm just a bit concerned that `or perhaps relying on the application protocol to decide which paths should be closed.` is understood as exactly that, an API suggestion. The suggestion being that even in presence of an API (application protocol), asking the application for a policy on on duplicate path closure is optional and can be dismissed.

I guess my concern is really with the words "the application protocol" (sounding like there is an API) vs "perhaps" (sounding almost dismissive to my ears).

How about: 

```
[..]. To avoid this pitfall, endpoints could
adopt a simple coordination rule, such as only letting the client
initiate closure of duplicate paths, or, if available, let the
the application protocol decide which paths should be closed.
```
That would actually be shorter (by four characters) than the current wording.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: To be honest, I don't really see the difference. You don't need a specific interface, because an application can already close a path anytime. So this is more saying, you may implement a default policy in the quic stack or just do nothing in the quic stack and rely on the application to the right thing (which might also be nothing).

comments.author: tzaeschke
comments.body: @mirjak Thanks, and my apologies, it turns out I managed to misread (even while rephrasing it) what it actually says here. It does say exactly what I wanted.

issues.title: Proposal for Integrating Deadline-Aware Streams into Multipath QUIC using DMTP
issues.author: tjohn327
issues.body:
### Motivation

With the rise of real-time applications such as teleoperation, live video streaming, and online gaming, there's an increasing demand for transport protocols that can efficiently handle strict latency requirements. Multipath QUIC enhances performance by utilizing multiple paths simultaneously, but it currently lacks mechanisms to guarantee data delivery within specific timeframes. Introducing deadline-aware streams to Multipath QUIC could enable applications to meet stringent latency constraints, optimizing for low-latency and high-reliability scenarios.
Additionally, the ability to have multiple paths using the same 4-tuple opens up the possibility of leveraging paths from path-aware networks like SCION, source routing, and others. This expands the pool of available paths beyond traditional IPv4 and IPv6 routes, potentially increasing the effectiveness of deadline-aware mechanisms like those proposed in DMTP.

#### Relevant Discussion

In a recent discussion around the Multipath Extension for QUIC ([Issue #378](https://github.com/quicwg/multipath/issues/378)), the use of multiple paths with the same 4-tuple found support. This aligns with the idea of integrating paths from path-aware networks, enabling Multipath QUIC to utilize all available paths provided by the system.

### How DMTP Fits In

The Deadline-aware Multipath Transport Protocol (DMTP) is tailored for deadline-sensitive communication over multiple paths. It employs strategies like smart retransmissions and Forward Error Correction (FEC) to optimize packet delivery based on latency deadlines, ensuring retransmissions occur only when they are likely to meet these deadlines. These methods align well with Multipath QUIC's capabilities, potentially allowing for efficient and reliable deadline-aware data transmission across different network paths.

### Key Concepts of DMTP

- Path Optimization: DMTP dynamically selects paths based on metrics like latency, bandwidth, and packet loss. This approach complements Multipath QUIC's ability to manage multiple paths effectively.
- Adaptive FEC: By integrating FEC, DMTP reduces the need for retransmissions, proactively adding redundancy when random losses are detected. This could enhance Multipath QUIC's congestion control mechanisms.
- Smart Retransmissions: DMTP only retransmits packets if they are predicted to meet the deadline, which helps to avoid unnecessary retransmissions. Incorporating this into QUIC's scheduling could improve overall efficiency.

For more detailed information on DMTP, please refer to our [paper](https://doi.org/10.23919/IFIPNetworking57963.2023.10186417).
We have developed a prototype implementation of DMTP, which we plan to open-source in the near future.

### How to get it integrated into Multipath QUIC

To integrate DMTP into Multipath QUIC, we propose implementing DMTP's mechanisms as a custom scheduler and congestion controller within the Multipath QUIC framework. Additionally, we suggest introducing a new transport parameter to signal support for deadline-aware streams during the handshake. For incorporating deadline information into data transmission, our proposal is to define an additional extension frame type called DEADLINE_CONTROL. The aim of this frame is to signal deadline-awareness for specific streams and indicate their associated deadlines.

### Request for Feedback

We're considering integrating deadline-aware streaming concepts from DMTP into Multipath QUIC and are interested in the community's perspective. Do you see value in this exploration? Are there potential challenges or compatibility concerns we should be aware of? Your feedback will be instrumental in guiding this proposal.

comments.author: LPardue
comments.body:
Hi @tjohn327 

Thanks for bringing your ideas here with a clear writeup.

However, this repository is for tracking issues and proposals for the text that is in scope of the Multipath QUIC extension itself.  

There will be many exciting opportunities and areas of research or innovation on top the completed multipath work. It sounds like you have an additional extension on top of that. The best venue to solicit interest or comments on that is on the QUIC mailing list. So I'd ask you to start a new thread there with your opening comment.

If there are specific issues or ideas you have on the multipath extension itself, that can ensure it is a good foundation for other ideas please do open specific issues or PRs (or contribute to existing ones). However, I want to be clear that we are now at the stage of the draft process where there is high bar for consensus on any new or major design changes.

comments.author: tjohn327
comments.body:
Thank you very much for your feedback and guidance @LPardue .

I understand that the Multipath QUIC draft is in its final stages, and I appreciate your suggestion to initiate a discussion on the QUIC mailing list.

I have prepared a [diff](https://github.com/quicwg/multipath/compare/main...tjohn327:multipath:deadline-aware-streams) with changes to incorporate deadline-aware streams into Multipath QUIC. While I recognize this may not fit within the immediate scope of the current draft, I thought it might be helpful to share this proposal here to gather initial impressions. I'm prepared to start a new thread on the QUIC mailing list to discuss this extension in detail with the broader community.

If time permits, I would greatly appreciate any initial thoughts on the diff or suggestions on how best to proceed. I'm eager to contribute positively and align with the group's direction.

Thank you again for your time and consideration.

comments.author: qdeconinck
comments.body: Given that these changes go further than a base multipath extension, I would suggest to write an individual draft and advertise it on the mailing list, as highlighted by Lucas. This is probably the best approach to motivate your extension, and maybe also motivate why multipath should be a requirement for your solution.

comments.author: LPardue
comments.body: Closing this as there is now a mailing list thread.

issues.title: Cross-path acknowledgments should be congestion controlled
issues.author: michael-eriksson
issues.body:
QUIC packets that only contain an ACK frame are not congestion controlled. [RFC 9000 states](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9000.html#section-13.2.1-3) that:

> _Since packets containing only ACK frames are not congestion controlled, an endpoint MUST NOT send more than one such packet in response to receiving an ack-eliciting packet._

When ACK-only packets are sent on another path than where the ack-eliciting packets were received, this requirement is obviously violated. A receiver of a big flow of packets could easily swamp a low-latency, low-bandwidth path by sending the acknowledgments there.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
The requirement in RFC 9000 is not about congestion control. It is about not having an infinite cycle of sending an ACK, receiving an ACK in return, ACKing that, etc.

The issue that you describe is also happening in asymmetric links, without using multipath. If the return path is too narrow, it could be congested by too many ACKs. RFC 9000 is silent about that, largely because previous attempts at congestion control of acknowledgements have been "inconclusive". Since ACKs are not immediately acknowledged, the congestion control loop is very loose, and thus very imprecise. You can easily reach a state where congestion control slows the sending of ACKs, which in turn slows the sending of data, etc.

In uni-path scenarios, the best protection against swamping the return path is to control ACK Frequency, which limits the number of ACKs sent per RTT. The big problem there is that the ACK Frequency draft does not mention multipath. It is probably too late to change that draft, so maybe we should write a companion draft, "ACK Frequency for Multipath". Basically, define a PATH_ACK_FREQUENCY frame similar to ACK Frequency but with a Path ID.

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
Christian wrote:
> The requirement in RFC 9000 is not about congestion control. It is about not having an infinite cycle of sending an ACK, receiving an ACK in return, ACKing that, etc.

Hmm, I think that the quote from RFC 9000 very explicitly mentions congestion control...

But I agree that congestion controlled ACKs can easily lead to infinite ack cycles.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
The sentence that you quoted does mention congestion control. The discussion of infinite loops happens a couple paragraphs later -- _An endpoint that is only sending non-ack-eliciting packets might choose to occasionally add an ack-eliciting frame to those packets to ensure that it receives an acknowledgment; see [Section 13.2.4](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9000.html#ack-tracking). In that case, an endpoint MUST NOT send an ack-eliciting frame in all packets that would otherwise be non-ack-eliciting, to avoid an infinite feedback loop of acknowledgments._

The spec does mention congestion control, as you said: _Since packets containing only ACK frames are not congestion controlled, an endpoint MUST NOT send more than one such packet in response to receiving an ack-eliciting packet_. That mean that if a node receives just one packet, it should send at most one ACK for that specific packet. It also implies that if you receive 2 or 3 packets, it is fine to send 2 or 3 ACKs. For example, if a node receives packets 1 and 2, it would be perfectly fine to send ACK 1-2 on path 1, and a copy of ACK 1-2 on path 2. Which would not address our problem, "avoid saturating a narrow return path".

The solution really is to send fewer ACKs overall, and that means adapting the ACK FREQUENCY draft for multipath.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
I agree that the problem discussed is not specific to a specific path and as such not specific to the multipath extension. I proposed to close the issue with no action.

The only thing we could do is to add a bit of discussion or a note of caution to not overload a path if one path is only used to send ACKs given they are not congestion control. But again this is effectively already a problem if you only have one path and send only ACKs in one direction. So not sure if even makes sense to explicitly say anything.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: @michael-eriksson can we close this issue?

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
Well, I don't think so. I can't see how an endpoint can be allowed to send (potentially large) non-congestion controlled traffic on _another_ path than where packet being acknowledged was received.

Maybe we should have a quick question on the wg mailing list for more views on the issue?

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: How is this different to the case where you send only ACKs in on direction on the _same_ path?

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
1. Most paths are reasonably symmetrical, so there is at least a fraction of the bandwidth available in the other direction. If the paths are separate, one can be "infinitely" smaller than the other.
2. Some paths, like some wireless paths, vary in capacity over time. This will affect both directions, so they will scale (more or less) equally in bandwidth. If the ACKs are sent over a separate path, its capacity can deteriorate without any reduction in the amount of sent ACKs.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: These are areas for experimentation but the basic problem exists in both cases.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: I propose closing this issue, because we do have great experience that ACK should not be congestion controlled in general -- whether on one path or another. We may want to open another issue regarding control of ACK frequency for multiple paths.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Do you mean we should say something in this draft about ACK frequency or would that be a separate draft?

I think the only we thing we can say right now is that the ack frequency is negotiated for all path and if different ack frequencies are need for different path, that would require a new extension. However, the ack frequency after all is a recommendation for a max value and of course the sender could still use different (smaller) delay on each path.

I guess we could add that as a short subsection to the implementation section...?

I that is not something useful to say. I recommend we mark this is as "separate draft" and leave it open for later.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: It absolutely should be a separate draft. I started working on a simple "PATH_ACK_FREQUENCY" draft, but quickly realized it is not that simple and that parallel "ships in the night" handling of each path will not necessarily work. For example, one of the motivation for ACK_FREQUENCY is to set a "budget of acknowledgements" so we send the right amount, don't cause CPU overload but also don't cause spurious timers. The "spurious timer" part could be set per path, because it is a function of the RTT of the path. But the "overload" part is a global setting. So, yes it is important, but No we should not try to do it as part of the main multipath draft.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Do you want to say anything about it in this draft?

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
I agree that a separate draft is the right thing to do.

Until it is available, I am strongly against the current (intended Standards Track!) document allowing, or even requiring, the transmission of huge amounts of acknowledgments on paths with completely unknown capacity and load.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
I am against adding text for that issue. We received strong feedback in Dublin that the draft was too researchy. If anything, we need to trim it to concentrate on presenting the mechanism and focusing on interop. Dropping half the text would be nice. 

Sending tons of packets on a narrow link is stupid. But we have to assume that developers are not stupid, and we cannot add text for each of the many ways in which they can do stupid things.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
We received feedback by one person that wasn't following the discussion super closely. I don't think we have to change our working approach based on this. We knew in advance that there are many open questions and therefore decided to focus on the basic mechanisms to manage paths (and e.g. not include address exchange). I think this is still what the draft does in the normative parts, and I agree we should not invent new normative requirements now without clear evidence. However, for recommendation and known issues we also have the implementation guidance section. And I still think it is correct to mention those issues that we know about there and potentially even give recommendation in cases where we already have some deployment of testing experience. (Again we should do an editorial pass and streamlined the document where possible but I would like to do that after this coming revision when we are don't to basically 0 issues.)

For this issue, I agree that we don't know enough to do a normative change here from RFC9000. Limiting ACK is a new mechanism that we don't have any experience which, e.g. what would be the right limit? However, we could still mention the issue in the implication guidance section to ensure that all implementor are at least aware of this. More concretely we could add one more sentence at the end of section 6.4 on [Packet Scheduling](https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#name-packet-scheduling) which already talks about ack strategies like this:

"As packets that only carries PATH_ACK frames are not congestion controlled, sending only PATH_ACK frames on a path should carefully consider the load induced by these packets, especially if the capacity is unknown on that path."

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
Yes, a caveat text like that is a reasonable stop gap measure until a separate document is ready.

However, the draft must also be changed to allow the transmission of `PATH_ACK` frames (but no other frames) on the same path also after having sent a `PATH_ABANDON` frame. The current draft forces an endpoint to send all acks of a full speed path on another path with unknown capacity (and even if it's known to be too narrow!).

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
This would be a mayor design change as PATH_ABANDON is meant to mean I won't send anything anymore on this path. Also we have a normative requirement that explicitly disallows that in section 3.3.2 (https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#ack-after-abandon):

"These PATH_ACK frames MUST be sent on a different path than the path being abandoned."

However, while the doc says "endpoints SHOULD send PATH_ACK frames promptly" (note this is a SHOULD), this doesn't mean you have to send "full speed" (whatever that means...?). You can decide yourself how many and how quickly you send the acks and of course you need to take the path capacity into account. I'd say "promptly" means don't delay them unnecessarily but of course only send them when you can safely do so.

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
It is not a major change, it's a very small one.

Sending a `PATH_ABANDON` frame implies that you won't send any more _data_ on that path. Sending in-path `PATH_ACK` frames (which of course are non-ack eliciting) is just for the peer's loss detection while the path is being shut down. The peer anyway has to be prepared to receive out-of-order packets from you after having received your `PATH_ABANDON` frame (especially if you send that on another path), and will trivially handle the acks that you send after the `PATH_ABANDON` _without any implementation change_!

With full speed I mean that the peer is sending data to you at the full available bandwidth of the link.

Quoting [RFC 9000](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9000.html#section-13.2.2-4):
> A receiver **SHOULD** send an ACK frame after receiving at least two ack-eliciting packets.

Most (all?) implementations of course follows this. Having separate ack transmission logic during path abandonment is a huge increase in complexity.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
PATH_ABANDON means that you don't send any new packets using the CID belong to the path ID indicated. This has nothing to do with data or not data. Changing that is a mayor change because current assumptions in path closure won't hold.

Acking every second packet is a fine strategy. If that leads to some ACK losses that is actually not a big problem. Usually the peer should stop sending you packets as soon as it receives the PATH_ABANDON so after one RTT anyway.

Also I would expect that it is rather unlikely that you send a PATH_ABANDON while the other end is currently sending full speed. E.g. you could first send a PATH_STANDBY and then later the PATH_ABANDON. Or if you do that, maybe also spending the effort of implementing a specific ack strategy for this case is worth it, especially if you have local knowledge about these other path. Nothing in the spec prevents you from optimising these corner cases. However, these are all the things where we don't know how this is used and we therefore cannot and should not say more.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: We added a warning in PR #478. Closing this issue now.

issues.title: Path abandonment is underspecified
issues.author: michael-eriksson
issues.body:
The exact sequence of events during path abandonment is underspecified (or maybe _underexemplified_) in the document. It is, however, [specifed](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-quic-multipath-11.html#section-7.2-7) that:

> _After sending the PATH_ABANDON frame, the endpoint MUST NOT send frames that use the Path ID anymore, even on other network paths._

This requirement is a little hard to parse, but if read literally it would mean that incoming packets could not be acknowledged after a `PATH_ABANDON` frame has been sent. This would imply that a whole RTT-flight of packets in the other direction would be unacknowledged and thus needlessly retransmitted.

This is the way I think that endpoint **A** abandoning a path with endpoint **B** should be done:

1. **A** stops sending new ack-eliciting packets on the path and waits for all packets in flight to be acknowledged or the tail loss probe timer to expire.
2. **A** sends a `PATH_ABANDON` frame to **B**. After that, **A** continues to acknowledge incoming packets from **B**, on the same or another path.
3. **B** receives and acknowledges the packet with the `PATH_ABANDON` frame. It does _not_ immediately send a reciprocal `PATH_ABANDON` frame, but first waits for acknowledgments of the packets it has in flight (just like **A** did before it sent its `PATH_ABANDON`).
4. When all of **B**'s packets in flight have been acknowledged, or the tail loss probe timer has expired, it send the `PATH_ABANDON` to **A** and removes all state is has for the path.
5. When **A** receives the `PATH_ABANDON` from **B**, it removes all state is has for the path and the path is completely abandoned.

This procedure also handles concurrent abandonment from both endpoints well.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Yes we need to correct the sentence to exclude PATH_ACKs. This was an oversight. I created PR #456.

However, the procedure described above is not correct and not what is specified in the draft. B has to sent the PATH_ABANDON immediately and then both endpoints wait for 3PTO after receiving the PATH_ABANDON before they remove state. As usually all packets sent before the PATH_ABANDON will receive before the PATH_ABANDON and therefore will be ACKed, there is no need to wait for the ACKs first. If there is re-ordering, that's why we have the 3 PTO waiting time. Also note that when you try to wait for the ACKs first, you also need a 3 PTO timer as they might never arrive. Therefore I don't think it's really useful to wait for the ACKs first.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
There is no oversight. The handling of acknowledgements is fully specified in:

_[3.3.2. ](https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#section-3.3.2)[Handling PATH_ACK for abandoned paths](https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#name-handling-path_ack-for-aband)_

_When an endpoint decides to send a PATH_ABANDON frame, there may still be some unacknowledged packets. Some other packets may well be in transit, and could be received shortly after sending the PATH_ABANDON frame. As specified above, the endpoints SHOULD send PATH_ACK frames promptly, to avoid unnecessary data retransmission after the peer deletes path resources._
_These PATH_ACK frames MUST be sent on a different path than the path being abandoned.PATH_ACK frames received after the endpoint has entirely deleted a path MUST be silently discarded._

The problem is in the sentence added at the end of section [7.2. ](https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#section-7.2)[PATH_ABANDON Frame](https://quicwg.org/multipath/draft-ietf-quic-multipath.html#name-path_abandon-frame). The text contradicts the more specification text in the "path close" section. That text should be replaced by a reference to path close.

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
Hmm, I wanted to initiate a discussion about the best way to do and specify path abandonment, by describing an efficient and clear procedure above. Let me be point more explicitly on some issues, using the same **A** (initiator) and **B** roles as in the example above:

### B's sending of `PATH_ABANDON`

Section 3.3 (Path Close) says:
> When an endpoint receives a PATH_ABANDON frame, it MUST send a corresponding PATH_ABANDON frame if it has not already done so.

It does not say _when_ this has to be done, and in particular what **B** is allowed to do before it sends the `PATH_ABANDON` frame. I argue above that **B** should wait until it has no packets in flight. When **A** then receives the `PATH_ABANDON`, it can directly delete all state for the path instead of waiting for 3PTO.

Forcing **B** to immediately send a `PATH_ABANDON` frame is pointless, it adds not information since **A** will anyway get an acknowledgment that the `PATH_ABANDON` frame it sent has been received.

### Sending in-path acknowledgments after having sent PATH_ABANDON

Section 3.3 (Path Close) says:
> The current draft does not allow sending acknowledgments for incoming packets on the same path after a PATH_ABANDON frame has been sent.

Why is this? Acknowledgements are often sent on same path, and there is no reason to not allow that when the path is closing down.

The draft supports _break-before-make_ path changes, e.g.:
> If the client received a PATH_ABANDON frame for the last open path, it MAY instead try to open a new path [...]

The only place to acknowledge the packets in flight would be on the same, last, path.

issues.title: Handling of PTO
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
Something that is not obvious how to handle in the draft is how one deals with cases when a path for a while drops all packets. 
The draft says in section: 

Data associated with the transmission and reception such RTT measurements, congestion control state, or loss recovery are maintained per packet number space and as such per Path ID.

So if one follows this one a PTO will eventually be triggered when there are no room to send more due to the congestion window. At this point from the paths perspective there are two things that can happen: 
1) A PTO functions and results in outstanding data being declared as lost. 
2) One abandon the path based on some other higher watch timer. 

There appear however be one issue with the above that is multipath specific. Namely that when the PTO fires the outstanding data could also be retransmitted on another path. But, following RFC 9002 the data will not be declared lost until a Probe actually makes it through to the peer and is being acked. 

Think it is worth clarifying this in the draft.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
On 11/2/2024 1:51 PM, Magnus Westerlund wrote:
> Something that is not obvious how to handle in the draft is how one deals with cases when a path for a while drops all packets.
> The draft says in section:
>
> Data associated with the transmission and reception such RTT measurements, congestion control state, or loss recovery are maintained per packet number space and as such per Path ID.
>
> So if one follows this one a PTO will eventually be triggered when there are no room to send more due to the congestion window.

This is actually a common scenario with Wi-Fi paths. We observe 
"suspension periods" of 100 or 200ms, much larger than a typical RTT of 
10 to 20ms.

>   At this point from the paths perspective there are two things that can happen:
> 1) A PTO functions and results in outstanding data being declared as lost.
> 2) One abandon the path based on some other higher watch timer.
Picoquic does something a bit different. If other paths are available, 
the packets will be declared lost, so their content can be resend 
immediately without risking delays, but the copy of the packets will be 
kept for a while. The lossy path will be placed in a "standby" state, no 
more content will be queued there. The stack will do a series of path 
challenges on the path, to check whether it comes back. If the path 
comes back it will be placed in available state again. If it turns out 
that packets were merely delayed instead of lost, it the acks will be 
processed, and the frames that were placed in the retransmission queue 
will be marked as received.

> There appear however be one issue with the above that is multipath specific. Namely that when the PTO fires the outstanding data could also be retransmitted on another path. But, following RFC 9002 the data will not be declared lost until a Probe actually makes it through to the peer and is being acked.
>
> Think it is worth clarifying this in the draft.

I don't know. we don't have a lot of experience, and solutions like the 
one I described above are still very close to research. Consider that 
RFC 9002 is largely advisory -- it describes a plausible default 
solution to congestion control and loss recovery, but it is not the last 
word on the issue. In fact, lots of implementations do congestion 
control very differently. We do not need to specify everything.

-- Christian Huitema

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body:
So fine with not being overly prescriptive. However, the issue I have is that if one just point an implementor that a path shall follow RFC 9000+9002 on a per path basis the handling of transmitted data can suffer significantly. This will need a bit of warning, especially as RFC 9002 says: 

Section 6.2:
`A PTO timer expiration event does not indicate packet loss and MUST NOT cause prior unacknowledged packets to be marked as lost. When an acknowledgment is received that newly acknowledges packets, loss detection proceeds as dictated by the packet and time threshold mechanisms; see [Section 6.1](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9002.html#ack-loss-detection).`

If one follows this MUST one will not declare the outstanding data as lost. Not declaring it lost I would say is considered correct for the path congestion controller aspect, however from the data handling perspective it is significantly sub-optimal if the path is unavailable a long time, or completely broken. I think there is a point here to include an implementation consideration on that this issue exists.

issues.title: Clarification on Path Migration in relation to opening a new path
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
Path Migration for the case when the client is not aware of the change, like for NAT address rebinding case can't be avoided. Thus, this needs to be supported by server as something that can occur. However, if a client have a new address it could technically select to migrate an existing path to this new path. However, it appears more suitable to have a very strong recommendation here to actually open a new path in these cases. Combined possibly with abandoning another existing path. 

This issue is based on the interop testing.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
The more I think about it, the more I believe that we should not try to support the "path migration" scenario. Currently, we have a very deterministic logic:

- identify the path by the path ID of the incoming packet.
- if the path ID was not seen yet, this is a new path.
- if the path ID exists already:
- if the 4 tuple match, and the CID match, no problem.
- if the CID is new, rotate the local CID
- if the 4 tuple does not match, treat that has a NAT traversal, challenge the old and the new address, retains the one for which the challenge works.

The "path migration" scenario breaks that logic. The CID is new, but it should not be rotated. Traffic should continue with the old CID, as in classic 9000. The server should only try to validate the new 4-tuple, not the old one. We have to reintroduce the concept of path-validating frames. We have to distinguish between NAT rebinding an migration by checking whether the CID is new, but we selected the unique-path-id architecture precisely because we know we cannot do that reliably.

Instead of attempting path migration of an existing path, applications have a much better solution: just create a new path with the new 4 tuple, and then abandon the old path after validating the new one. This gives us a safe migration.

During the interop testing, picoquic was reacting poorly to the migration attempt. I think I fixed that by simply ignoring any path challenge received on a different 4 tuple on an existing path. That means falling back to the NAT traversal code if someone attempts a "path migration". It will probably move the confusion to the implementation that is attempting these migrations, which I believe is fair since they should not be doing that in the first place.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: There is a related issue with handling of the server preferred address, see issue #460.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: @huitema can you explain the problem in the case where you receive a packet with a new CID on a new tuple for an in-use path ID. This case is not special and should simply work inline with path migration as specified in RFC9000. Of course we should recommend to open a new path instead but it should like you think there is an actual problem here that needs fixing and it's not clear to me what exactly the problem is...?

comments.author: Yanmei-Liu
comments.body:
In the current draft, when endpoint receive a new packet, it decides with the packet DCID:
- Different path ID, same / different 4-tuple, using a different path
- Same path ID, same 4-tuple, using the same path
        - New CID, CID rotation on the same path
- Same path ID, different 4-tuple, NAT-rebinding or migration
        - Same CID, NAT-rebinding
        - New CID, Path Migration

My opinion is that whether choose to create a new path or using path migration, it depends on the endpoint want 2 paths at the same time or not. Further more, it depends on whether the endpoint want to send packets with 2 different address at the same time or not.
If it only wants to use one path at the same time, but still wants to continuesly sending packets through different address, path migration would be a good choice.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
Look at the [minutes of QUIC for IETF 118](https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-118-quic#). we had a long discussion of precisely 'simultaneous rebinding + CID rotation', that was one of the key arguments for moving to the "unique path id" design. See also the old issue #188.

The problem is that there are four possible events:  CID rotation, NAT rebinding, NAT rebinding with simultaneous CID rotation, and migration. I wrote a summary of scenario in the following table, in which:

* Observation is what the peer sees: CID, which in all cases  point to the same path ID, and 4-tuple
* Whether verification is needed or not.
* What to do if verification fails.

The results for the peer are:

Event | Observation | Verification needed | If verification fails
-------|--------------|-----------------------|----------
CID rotation | Different CID, same 4-tuple | No | Cannot fail
NAT rebinding | Same CID, same 4-tuple | Yes | retain old 4 tuple
NAT rebinding with simultaneous CID rotation | Different CID, different 4-tuple | Yes | retain old 4 tuple, use new CID
Migration | Different CID, different 4-tuple | Yes | retain old 4 tuple, use old CID (per RFC 9000). In case of success, wait for validating frames before using the new 4-tuple

In various discussions, we pointed out that NAT rebinding with simultaneous CID rotation is actually a frequent case. Suppose that there is a gap in traffic, a few seconds of silence. The longer the silence, the higher the probability that a NAT rebinding happen. But for privacy reasons, many stacks perform a CID rotation after a long silence. It is very likely that many NAT rebinding will also be associated with CID rotation.

We have an ambiguity between two scenarios that present the same symptoms to the peer, yet require a different handling. The best way to solve that ambiguity is to never use path migration, and always treat arrival of a new four tuple as a NAT rebinding, whatever the value of the CID.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body:
I think you made some errors in the table above @huitema. I think an important difference is if the packet contain a Path Challenge or not. And in addition shouldn't the NAT rebinding have "Different 4-tuple"? So I think my version of this table is the following: 

Event | Observation | Verification needed | If verification fails
-- | -- | -- | --
CID rotation | Different CID but matching this path, same 4-tuple | No | Cannot fail
NAT rebinding | Same CID, different 4-tuple | Yes | retain old 4 tuple
NAT rebinding with simultaneous CID rotation | Different CID, different 4-tuple | Yes | retain old 4 tuple, use new CID
Migration | PC + new CID for existing path, different 4-tuple | Yes | retain old 4 tuple, use old CID (per RFC 9000). In case of success, wait for validating frames before using the new 4-tuple
New PATH | PC + CID for new Path ID | Yes | Path failed to be established, PC can be retried with the same CID. 

So I think another aspect here are what would you do if one gets a Migration even if we recommend against it or would consider forbidding it. Protocol violation? And can we really take things to that state considering what RFC 9000 says?

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: If someone attempted a migration, I would treat it the same as a NAT Rebinding.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: We are replacing the "migration" process of RFC 9000 by the path creation process, yes.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: I don't want to make any difference based on the content of packets. We also discussed that before, that was one of the proposals before adopting unique ID. Any packet can contain a PATH CHALLENGE at any time. It is actually a pretty good way to implement a "keep alive" process for a path.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: So I still don't think there is a problem. If you see a new 4-tuple on an existing path ID, it's a migration (NAT rebinding is always migration). If you want to send on a new 4-tuple that you haven't validated yet, you must validate it. If you receive a path_challange, you should reply to it (on the same 4 tuple). that's it!

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
Based on a discussion with @mirjak, @gloinul and @Yanmei-Liu, I think we could have the following resolution:

1) Add a strong recommendation to use multipath mechanisms for the migration scenarios, because they are much more controlled and deterministic than the basic migration in 9000. The multipath mechanisms allow "make before break", using PATH_AVAILABLE and PATH_BACKUP frames to control where to send traffic, and PATH_ABANDON to cleanly "break" one path after other paths are available.

2) Add some text explaining that we do have some ambiguity in RFC 9000 between the "uncontrolled" NAT Rebinding scenario and the "controlled" migration scenarios. This ambiguity can be resolved using heuristics, but the heuristics will get confused some time. Implementations that do not want to rely on these heuristics can simplify their code by only supporting the NAT Rebinding scenario. This will drop support for scenarios like "prepare a migration, validate the continuity of the 4-tuple, then keep the 4-tuple in standby until the app decides to use it" -- NAT Rebinding only does immediate migration, if the old path is still available, the new attempt is discarded.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: @huitema on your point 2 above: I think this is, if at all, an issue for RFC9000 and not for this draft. Therefore I don't think we should  add any discussion in this draft. Actually I disagree about this problem. I don't think there is ambiguity but instead it was on purpose a decision in RFC9000 to treat these two cases the same. If you decide to not implement migration as specified in RFC9000 for both cases then that's your local decision and migration will fail in some cases. That's okay but has nothing to do with the multipath extension.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: @huitema we are ready to merge PR #469. Do you think this would address this issue or do you think we need anymore discussion on your point 2 above?

issues.title: Clarify interaction between PATHS_BLOCKED and PATH_NEW_CONNECTION_ID
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
In the MP-QUIC interop testing at IETF 121 it was observed that an issue when testing PATHS_BLOCKED is that some servers where blocking path creation by not providing CIDS for some of the path IDs that it allowed. Thus, the client may desire to open more paths, there are agreed on path IDs, but lacks the CIDs. If the PATHS_BLOCKED is usable, how does one handle the situation when the server block the client by not providing CIDs? 

I believe some clarifications and possible requirements are needed. I think there are two roads to take here:

1) Require that endpoints provide PATH_NEW_CONNECTION_ID when there are no CIDs for an unused PATH ID, as long as below MAX_PATH_IDS. 
2) Create an equivalent or parameter on PATHS_BLOCKED indicating what is the issue.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
For the record, the observation during interop was due to an off-by-1 bug in picoquic, which has since be fixed. But the situation could be repeated.

There are a couple reasons why an endpoint might delay provision of CIDs. The Path CID frames can only be sent after the max path id is negotiated, so there will always be a delay. That delay will be longer if packets are lost and need to be repeated. If the client is getting impatient, I think that something like "PATH_CID_BLOCKED" with a path_id parameter would make sense. If after sending that the client still does not receive the expected CID, it can escalate. Maybe abandon the path.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: So picoquiche had the off-by-one issue. QUICHE does not provide CIDs period up to the level of max_initial_path_ids. Thus, I think we need to think about how to deal with this situation. I agree that there are reasons for delaying provisioning CIDs for Paths, but what a peer can expect needs to be made clear.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Based on the discussion at IETF 121 we will propose a PR to add a field to the PATHS_BLOCKED frame and an error code the PATH_ABANDON frame.

issues.title: Clarification on Preferred Address handling
issues.author: huitema
issues.body:
The current draft (version 11) says _"Also, the Path ID for the connection ID specified in the "preferred address" transport parameter is 0. Use of the "preferred address" is considered as a migration event that does not change the Path ID."_ This point is further reinforced in the path management section: _"In particular, if the server uses the preferred_address transport parameter, clients cannot assume that the initial server address and the addresses contained in this parameter can be simultaneously used for multipath (Section 9.6.2 of [QUIC-TRANSPORT])."_

This is questionable, since support of RFC-9000 style "migration" is problematic, as explained in issue #458. With multipath negotiated, "path migration" uses the same code path as "NAT Rebinding", which is a poor fit for preferred address migration. The selected path will eventually depend on the order in which packets are received, which might bring back usage of the original address instead of the preferred address. 

Clients will get a much more reliable result if they proceed in two steps: first establish a new path to the preferred address (typically path id 1), then abandon the initial path (path id 0). This is the "make before break" scenario that should generally be preferred to path migration. But this behavior is gated by two conditions: the server should allow a "max path id" value no lower than 1; and, the server shall provide the client with connection IDs for path 1. Otherwise, the client will have to wait until the server sends a new MAX_PATH_ID and PATH_CONNECTION_ID frames.

We may want to revise the text to explicitly authorize "make before break" behavior, i.e., using path creation instead of path migration for handling the preferred address. If we don't do that, stacks would probably need a special handling of the preferred address, as an exception to the normal code behavior, and that special handling should probably be discussed in the implementation section.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I don't think we need to do anything here as well also allow opening new path before/instead of the preferred address migration. If an endpoint indicated a max path id of 0, it a clear sign it effectively doesn't want to used multipath (yet) and especially for the preferred address might prefer migration. So the only thing we could/should explicitly recommend is that if the max path is larger than 0, then a new path should be used instead of migration for the preferred address.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: There is a small matter of timing. There will be some time between "max path is larger than 0" and "a CID is available for path=1".

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: @huitema but that means it's better to treat this as migration and keep using path ID 0, no? Are any changes needed here or can we close the issue?

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
Migration is never better than creation of a new path followed by deletion of the old path -- the path creation allows proper make before break, which RFC 9000 style migration does not. And yes, in that case that means deleting path 0. But given what we have written, we can have server implementations that delay providing CID for path 1 until migration of path 0 to the preferred address is complete. Combine that with a stubborn client that does not do migration, and we have an interop problem.

I guess part of the issue is that I treated the old "migration" code as "creating a path". It does something else, merely validating a 4 tuple. The path creation only happens in RFC 9000 when the client actually migrates a path to a new tuple -- a different concept than what we do with path creation. I don't have time to fix that immediately, but should be able to review it in December.

But then, RFC 9000 migration relies on the concept of "path validating frames". I hoped I could get rid of that.

Looking at it that way opens interesting possibilities. For example, I could do an address validation exchange using a CID allocated for path X, then use the validated address to immediately send data on a new path Y, then close the unrelated path Z. I kind of like that approach.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Okay, I understand the issue in your implementation but I don't think we can or should change anything in the draft.

If we would define the path ID to be 1 for the CID provided by the preferred_address parameter that would mean that we have a dependency between transport parameters where a preferred address can only be used if the initial_max_path_id is set to at least 1. Not sure I like that. Also we should maybe consider to reserve path ID 1 than only for the preferred address to avoid ambiguity but that seems a bit ugly, too.

However,  I don't think we should take on another such design change if there is not really an unsolved problem that needs fixing or otherwise things don't work. I guess this could be still addressed in a separate extension at a later point of time if that is seen as a valuable thing...?

Therefore I still propose that we close this issue for now without any changes.

issues.title: PATHS_ BLOCKED should be clearly labelled "informational"
issues.author: huitema
issues.body: The interop tests showed mismatched expectations, with some stacks apparently expecting to promptly receive a new MAX_PATH_ID frame after sending a PATH_BLOCKED frame. Of course, that's not happening. If the number of allocated paths has reached the limit supported by the server, the MAX_PATH_ID value can only increase if some allocated paths are abandoned. We should maybe clarify that PATH_BLOCKED is purely informational, and that it is not expected to trigger changes in the state of the peer.

issues.title: Recommend that PATH_ABANDON should be retransmitted on another path
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: Maybe this is obvious but if a path_abandon frame gets lost, this will usually lead to a PTO. In this case the path is highly likely to be already broken and I probably should retransmit the path_abandon frame on another path to actually be able to close the path. We already say in the new "handling PTO" section that it makes sense to generally retransmit on another path. However, maybe we should actually say this using normative language (SHOULD or MUST?) in the path closure section in case of the path_abandon frame?

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: The feedback from Dublin was quite clear: a bunch of these strategies are still research issues. We should generally not try to solve them as part of the draft, because it makes the whole draft look like a research project. And we should certainly not make normative statements that implementation SHOULD or MUST implement a variant of an algorithm for which research is still ongoing.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Actually we already have this sentence in section 3.3 (Path Closure):

> Thus, even if connectivity on that path is already broken but there is still another usable path, it is RECOMMENDED to send the PATH_ABANDON frames on another path.

I would maybe just like to add one more sentence here to make the case above a bit more clear like this:

> Thus, even if connectivity on that path is already broken but there is still another usable path, it is RECOMMENDED to send the PATH_ABANDON frames on another path. For example if the PATH_ABANDON frame itself got lost on the to be abandoned path, this might be a sign that the path is not usable anymore and retransmission on another path would address this concern.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I created PR #473 to see the proposed change in context.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I closed #473 but based on the discussion there created PR #477. This new PR is a slight rephrasing of the existing sentence but makes it now clear that it is generally recommend to send the PATH_ABANDON on another path. That was the take-away for me from the discussion on #473. Please let me know if you agree to that or not!

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: PR #477 was merged.

issues.title: If the peer does not reply with a path_abandon frame, state can never be removed
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
Currently the draft only says:

"knowledge of the connection identifiers received from the peer and of the state of the number space associated to the path SHOULD be retained while packets from the peer might still be in transit, i.e., for a delay of 3 PTO after the PATH_ABANDON frame has been received from the peer"

Therefore state removal is triggered by reception of the path abandon frame. There is MUST in the text that my peer must send me a path_abandon frame if it has received mine. What if it doesn't send a path_abandon frame ever?

The sentence above is only a SHOULD, so I guess you could remove state any reasonable time after sending the path_abandon frame, however, maybe we should say more explicitly that it makes sense to also start a timer after the ACK for the path_abandon frame was received, or stop retransmitting the path_abandon frame after X tries and then just remove state?

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: If a peer misbehaves, as in "doesn't send a path_abandon frame ever", you should treat that as an attack. Very much a variant of the Slow loris attack described in the security section of RFC 9000. Closing the connection would be appropriate.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: It's a bit hard to enforce as the PATH_ABANDON frame can get lost and need to be retransmitted. So you basically would need to start a timer after sending the PATH_ABANDON frame and the close the connection after N x 3 PTOs where N is the number of expected retransmission approaches. That seems a bit to radical for me. However, I think we either need to specify this or re-define when state can be finally removed.

comments.author: qdeconinck
comments.body: While a peer may indeed misbehave, there may be specific pattern losses making the PATH_ABANDON frame never reach the peer. While the reception of the PATH_ABANDON frame will lead to removal of path state after some delay, it would make sense to me to apply this 3 PTO delay when the PATH_ABANDON is sent. At some point, the peer that has sent the PATH_ABANDON will abandon the path anyway, and dropping state related to the path will just, in the case the PATH_ABANDON does not reach the peer, make the host ignore all incoming packets mapping to that path, such that the peer would interpret this as a completely lossy path that it can eventually abandon. Note that if a PATH_ABANDON is deemed lost, the sender should always resend it, even if the related path state is no more present.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
You have start a start a timer after sending the PATH_ABANDON frame anyway because you may have to retransmit it. I think what we need is to also start a timer after the ACK for the PATH_ABANDON has been received and also specify that the PATH_ABANDON should not be retransmitted more than X time and when you stop retransmitting you also remove all path state.

I guess we could also say that you can remove most path state after the first PTO and then only keep information about the PATH_ABANDON in order to retransmit it. But not sure if that makes a big difference.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
I think that we should point out the issue and leave the implementers a choice.

As discussed in the WG, we do not have a lot of experience with deployment. This is kind of a research area, and we are exhausting ourselves trying to provide operational guidance or implementation guidance. There are indeed multiple choices:

1) Start a timer after sending the first path Abandon, then close the connection with an error code if the path abandon from the peer is not received in time. Of course, all solutions based on timers introduce some fragility, so the timer will have to be large.

2) Same, but start the timer after the Path Abandon frame is acknowledged. More complicated than 1 because you need to track ACKs, and same fragility.

3) Do nothing. After all, the only effect of having a path lingering in limbo is to reduce the number of path-id available for path creation. If you don't need to create a new path, there is no real issue. This is the option with the least side effects.

4) Put the path in some explicit limbo state after the Abandon is acked or after a short timer. In that state, drop all incoming packets, never ack them. Kinda like doing nothing, but with fewer resource allocated locally.

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
FWIW, I think choice number 3 is the correct one. An endpoint should however be allowed to ignore any incoming packets after some (unspecified) time.

Setting a timer to abort the connection is needlessly complex and brutal, and can easily have false positives if the peer's PATH_ABANDON frame is retransmitted.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
@michael-eriksson if you say the endpoint should be allow to ignore incoming packets that is option 4.

Anyway, I think we agree that we want to note the issue but don't specify anything normatively. So I created PR #475. Please have a look!

comments.author: michael-eriksson
comments.body:
> @michael-eriksson if you say the endpoint should be allow to ignore incoming packets that is option 4.

My view is that the endpoint MAY do option 4, but shouldn't have to.

> Anyway, I think we agree that we want to note the issue but don't specify anything normatively. So I created PR #475. Please have a look!

Looks good to me!

issues.title: Rename PATHS_BLOCKED to PATH_BLOCKED
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body: Currently all the other multipath frame types are PATH_ except PATHS_BLOCKED. And really the description for PATHS_BLOCKED really just indicates that one path was blocked from being established. Section 4.1:
`If the IV is larger than 96 bits, the path-and-packet-number is left-padded with zeros to the size of the IV.`
 
I think the "If the IV is larger ..." should rather be "If the Nonce field for the used AEAD algorithm is larger ..."

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
I think the text is correct as it and inline with RFC9000. This is what RFC9000 says:

```
The key and IV for the packet are computed as described in Section 5.1. The nonce, N, is formed by combining the packet protection IV with the packet number. The 62 bits of the reconstructed QUIC packet number in network byte order are left-padded with zeros to the size of the IV. The exclusive OR of the padded packet number and the IV forms the AEAD nonce.
```

Also the size of the IV is mentioned in RFC9000 to be the size of the nonce with a reference to RFC5116. This seems a bit circular but I don't think we need or should specify this here a second time:

```
The Length provided with "quic iv" is the minimum length of the AEAD nonce or 8 bytes if that is larger; see [[AEAD](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5116)].
```

I think we can close this issue...?

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body:
So I was partially wrong in my issue. I realize thanks to your citations here. But, I think there are still an issue. So per RFC 9001 Section 5.1 the IV is derived using a key derivation function using the label "quic iv". But that resulting IVs length is to my understanding depending on the selected cipher hash functions and what length it outputs:

Section 5.1 of RFC 9001:
`  The keys used for packet protection are computed from the TLS secrets
   using the KDF provided by TLS.  In TLS 1.3, the HKDF-Expand-Label
   function described in Section 7.1 of [TLS13] is used with the hash
   function from the negotiated cipher suite.  All uses of HKDF-Expand-

The IV length appears cipher dependent, thus it is possible that if one would arrive at a cipher that has an IV that is shorter than 96 bits the behavior is undefined. I think the relevant text for this discussion is this part of RFC 8446

The length of the TLS per-record nonce (iv_length) is set to the

issues.title: Managing ACK and repeat of PATH_CID_BLOCKED frame
issues.author: huitema
issues.body:
Suppose that the packet carrying a PATH_CID_BLOCKED frame is lost. How does the implementation decide whether that frame should be repeated?

For the paths blocked frame, we have a good logic: if a the packet containing a path blocked frame is lost, compared the "pax path id" in the blocked frame to the highest value of the max path id in a PATHS_BLOCKED frame acknowledged by the peer. If the value is higher than the retained value, repeat. Otherwise, don't. But we don't have anything like that for the PATH_CID_BLOCKED blocked frame.

One possibility is to repeat it no matter what, but this may create extra traffic. Another is to never repeat it, but that means losing the signal. Yet another would be to remember if the PATH_CID_BLOCKED frame for that path was already acknowledged, but what if we need to send several such frames for the same path over time? We could also test whether the path is still blocked.

I think this is a bit under-specified.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
The way I implemented it is as follow:

1. when the application sends a PATH_CID_BLOCKED frame, set a flag in the path context, "currently sending a path CID blocked frame"

2. When an ACK for the packet carrying the frame is received, clear that flag.

3. If a packet carrying a PATH_CID_BLOCKED frame is lost, check whether the path still exists (it may have been abandoned and deleted) and whether the flag is set. If both conditions are true, repeat the frame, otherwise just forget it.

comments.body:

Not sure we need to specify the retransmission behavior in detail but probably need to say something, maybe just like: MAY retransmit if still blocked. (For MAX_PATH_ID it's probably a SHOULD or even MUST retransmit?)

issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
We discussed today in the interop call if the PATH_CIDS_BLOCKED frame is really needed because usually the peer should provide at least one unused CID for all active paths, otherwise this seems to be rather an implementation error. Also there is no really good reason to not just provide at least one CID for all paths up to the max path id limit. If you want to limit the number of paths, just set a lower max path id limit. This could be clarified in the draft.

However, the use case to send PATH_CIDS_BLOCKED frame when you want to open a new path but are not blocked by the max path id but instead by the fact that you didn't get any CID for an unused path ID seemed still relevant as this behaviour is allowed and therefore might not be an implementation error.

issues.title: Abandon path, 3*PTO and idle timer
issues.author: huitema
issues.body:
Reading the draft-13 more closely, I see a bit of a contradiction between 3.3.3 and 3.4.

Section 3.3.3 on "idle timeout" says: "_An endpoint can decide to close a path at any time, whether the path is in active use or not, by sending a PATH_ABANDON frame.  It is not required to send a PATH_ABANDON frame at any specific point in time.  For example, an endpoint may wait until it will anyway send another frame._"

Section 3.4 on "Path Close" says: "_If a peer sends a PATH_ABANDON frame but never receives a corresponding PATH_ABANDON frame, it might not be able to remove path state. It is left to the implementation to handle this unexpected behavior as it does not impact interoperability. If the endpoint is no longer willing to process the issued connection IDs for the abandoned path, it MAY close the connection, but SHOULD wait at least 3 PTOs after sending the PATH_ABANDON frame._"

The text in 3.3.3 is motivated in part by radio management. On a mobile device, sending any packet requires powering up the radio, which consumes energy. It is better to power the radio once and send a few packets in a batch than to power the radio multiple time. But if the endpoint waits until "something else has to be sent", it may wait more than 3*PTO, and the peer MAY close the connection. Not good.

I do not agree that this works.

For starter, it does not work if the server uses a zero length CID. It that case, in order to create a new path, a client sends a probe with a zero length CID. It arrives at the server on a five tuple that the server has not yet seen. How can the server know which encryption context it should use? comments.body: Maybe I'm missing something but why will it _mostly_ relate to the shortest path? Isn't it kind of random which path the highest ack'ed packet belongs to?

Consider a scenario with two paths, A and B, where the latency of A is larger than the B's one. The sender wants to send two packets, spread on both paths. We have two cases.

1. 1 sent on B, 2 sent on A

There are two sub-cases here.

- The receiver sends an ACK before having received 2. `ACK(largest=1)` contains the ACK delay relative to path B. Then it receives 2, and sends `ACK(largest=2)` with ACK delay relative to path A. In this case, we have ACK delay for both paths.

- The receiver waited for 2 before sending its ACK. Then, the ACK delay of `ACK(largest=2)` relates to path A, and we don't have the host delay of path B.

2. 1 sent on A, 2 sent on B

While we still have the two sub-cases, they both lead to the same result: `ACK(largest=2, missing=1)` and `ACK(largest=2)` have their ACK delay relative to the host delay of path B and not to the path A.

In general, if the largest packet number has been sent on the lowest latency path, it will prevent the receiver from advertising the host delay of higher latency paths. Note that the "ideal case" (where both paths have estimates) only works if the sender does not transmit further packets on the fast path, in which case we fall into case 2. As the fast path will get its packets acknowledged quicker, the sender will likely send further packets on fast path first. It might still be possible to get host delay estimates of slower paths, but most of the ACK delays will relate to the fast one.
Ah okay, the assumption is that you would basically receive all packets on the slow path "out-of-order". Got it now. Thanks!
I think the word "mostly" is a bit confusing. It could be that when someone uses a round-robin scheduler, unfortunately, it always measures the delay of the high latency path.
Would replacing "mostly" by "most of the time" be better?

comments.author: yfmascgy
comments.body:
> The old text was stating "do not send if no non-probing packet received over 3 RTT". The new text essentially adds "do not send if no non-probing packet received or acknowledged over 3 RTT." At first sight it looks right, but there is a tension. Suppose that, as a receiver, I wish the sender would stop sending on a path. With the old rule, I can simply stop sending on that path. With the new rule, I would have to also stop acknowledging packets, even if those packets were received correctly. That's not natural, a tension between signalling path preference and creating artificial losses. All considered, I would rather keep the old text.

My understanding is that if I am a receiver that wants to proactively cause a sender to stop sending, I should use the explicit way of sending a path abandon frame. The idle timeout handles the case when a receiver is unaware of a path change that leads to communication failure. If that is the purpose, as long as the receiver can receive packets in the sender-to-receiver direction and acknowledge on another path, it looks to me that we should still allow the sender to use that path. But I feel if we do that, we are diverging from the bidirectional nature of a path described in the draft, which worths more discussion.

This sentence covers the case where a path was idle for a while and therefore should be closed silently as it might not work anymore anyway. However, if you have received packet on the path or have an indication that packets you've sent on the path were received by the other end, the path is clearly not idle and working. I also agree with @yfmascgy that that means you only know for sure that the path is still working in one direction and that might need further discussion.

comments.body:
```suggestion
in the last 3 path RTTs or (b) no non-probing packet sent over this
```

The use of "or" is ambiguous. We want to say that receiving data in one direction proves that the receiving direction works, and receiving acknowledgements proves that the sending direction works. Stop sending should logically be tied to the sending direction. If packets sent on a path are not acked, then the node should stop sending because the path is probably broken. But isn't that already covered? 

I think the text mixes two issues: stop sending because the path is broken; and, stop sending because the peer would rather not use it anymore. The peer not sending "non probing" data on the path may be an indication that it does not want to use it anymore. Or it may be an indication that it has nothing to send right now. Which means the signal is ambiguous, and using ambiguous signals is a bad idea. I think we should come down to two simple ideas:

* nodes should monitor the quality of paths. If packets sent on the path are not acked, that means the quality is bad and the path should probably not be used.
* nodes that want they peer to stop using a specific path should signal it using "abandon path" frame.
I agree with the two simple ideas described above, I think it makes things much more clear.

I also agree with the simpler ideas. The host should stop sending packets on a path if a) it experiences too many losses (i.e., they never got acknowledged), or b) a ABANDON_PATH frame has been sent/received concerning that path.
@qdeconinck @huitema are you saying a node should not consider a path a closed if it was idle for RTTs? This was the original intent of the text.

My point here is to have clear signals. I think we could leave an "idle timer" per path, but idle means "no sent packets acknowledged not received packets" on that path, and the duration of the (local) path idle timer should have been advertised (e.g., we could reuse the max_idle_timeout transport parameter per path, or define a new one if needed).
Reusing the negotiated idle timer is the simpler solution for now.

This is linked to a previous discussion on issue #51 . At that time, we were wondering whether to we should use max_idle_timeout or define something like max_path_idle_timeout. The max_idle_timeout in RFC9000 is used to close the whole connection, so maybe we want something per-path?

Defining an idle timer per path would make control more precise. It would also be one more parameter that administrators will have to worry about. How do you set up this new parameter? Should it be the same for every path? How would it relate to the globally negotiated idle timer? I am not sure that the complexity is worth it. If a node wants to abandon a path before the globally defined timer expires, they can always explicitly abandon the path before the timer expires. I would rather keep it simple and have just one timer.

Okay, we can have more discussion on issues #51. For now and for this PR, is the proposal to replace "in the last 3 path RTTs" with "for at least max_idle_timeout milliseconds" or do we want some entirely different text? If so, please propose a new PR!

I think, for now, we can replace the 3-RTT with the max_idle_timeout as Mirja @mirjak proposed. Regarding whether we want something per-path, if the timeout value is large enough, I prefer what Christian @huitema suggested that we have one timer. However, if we want a shorter timeout (something like 3 times RTT), then we might want to have a per-path timer because of path heterogeneity (For example, a 5G path's RTT could be much smaller than that of the other paths).
