reviews.author: huitema
reviews.body:
We already have a specification that sequence number must be monotonically increasing for frames sent on the same path. This means that sequence number comparison are per path. The implementers MUST remember the latest number received for a path in order to discard old values. We have an implementation choice. Implementers can obtain the "monotonically increasing" property with one counter per path, or one global counter. The global counter solution requires less memory, so it seems preferable, but insisting that counters are per path would needlessly force the less efficient implementation.

We may want to say somewhere that receivers MUST NOT compare the receive values for a path ID with received values for other path IDs.

comments.body:
I think there is a simpler way to state this requirement, by focusing at the receiver rather than the sender.

I would state:
PATH_AVAILABLE frame and monotonically increasing values MUST be used for PATH_AVAILABLE and PATH_BACKUP frames sent for the same Path ID.

This would replace the paragraph As the sequence space is per path... for each Path ID.
I think the correction is not needed, and in fact confusing. The previous text explicitly state that the comparison is "for the same path ID", i.e., that the number is compared per path.

```suggestion
or PATH_AVAILABLE frame for the same Path ID with a Path Status sequence number
```

Previous to this PR, the sequence number was assumed to be per connection. This PR changes it to be per path and I think this edit is needed to clarify this. However, in any case we have an open issue that the current text is a bit unclear if the seq number is per path or per connection and we need to clarify this in one or the other way. I agree with the issue that this need more clear text and I disagree with you @huitema that this additional is not needed or confusing. Not doing anything will be confusing. However, note this PR actually proposes a change to the current approach (maybe that's what confused you?). We could also have a PR that just clarifies the current approach (per connection seq numbers) but clarification is needed in any way.

This requirement is already stated above in the definition of the field and we should not write it down twice:

 > A variable-length integer specifying the per-path sequence number assigned for
 > this PATH_STANDBY frame. The sequence number space is shared with the
 > PATH_AVAILABLE frame and monotonically increasing values MUST be used.

This paragraph is just an additional note to make things completely obvious. It's not necessarily needed but given this is a late change and it might confuse people, I think it's better to be crystal clear.

I think this is correctly stated in the existing text:
~~~
Frames may be received out of order. A peer MUST ignore an incoming
PATH_STANDBY frame if it previously received another PATH_STANDBY frame
or PATH_AVAILABLE frame for the same Path ID with a
Path Status sequence number equal to or higher than the Path Status
sequence number of the incoming frame.
~~~
Your proposed change merely removes the line breaks. I am not opposed to that, but it is hardly necessary.

Specifically, I don't want to say "as the sequence is per path". I would be OK with something simple like:
~~~
Path Status Sequence Number:
: A variable-length integer specifying the sequence number assigned for
  this PATH_STANDBY frame. The sequence number space is shared with the
  PATH_AVAILABLE frame and monotonically increasing values MUST be used
  for PATH_STANDBY or PATH_AVAILABLE frame related to the same path-ID.
~~~

My point is that we should not force implementations to have a send counter per path, since having a global send counter works just fine.

Note that you always have to hold per path state at the receiver, e.g. even if you have per connection seq numbers if you receive first seq 2 for path 1 and then seq 1 for path 2 both are valid and both need to be processed. But in both approaches you never have to keep per path state in the sender (if you don't want to). So even if the seq number is path you can still implement a global sequence number in the sender and you are fine. However, in theory if you have a per-connection number you potentially also would need to additionally check if the number is monotonically increasing across all path which is just unnecessary.

But again the current text is unclear and we should clearly spell out on or the other approach. The question really is, is receiving the same seq number with a differs path ID an error or not and I don't think it is any helpful if it is. That's what the text tries to explain and make sure it is really clear.
Okay now I'm confused myself. You are right this is no change and this text is already saying that the seq number is per path... but then this PR is fine, no?

If I have time, I will try to propose a PR on the PR.

I think the main remaining issue is that we have duplicate text for Available and Standby. If we get rid of the duplication, we can end up with something simple.

reviews.author: huitema
reviews.body:
Hum. Little bit of fumble. I wanted to make a PR on top of @mirjak but Github ended up merging my proposal directly into mirja's branch. I would not be offended if someone just rolled that commit back.

On the other hand, my proposal has a couple of advantages:

1) Since most of the text for Standby and Available is common, merging in a single section saves almost a full page of spec. Plus, it guarantees that we don't end up with two slightly different views of sequence number management in the two sections.

2) @mirjak and I actually agree on most points of the text, and the spec was indeed already specifying that sequence number comparisons for Standby and Abandon are per path-id. The text does not change that.

3) @mirjak insisted on belaboring the point so receivers don't go on doing global comparisons of the sequence number across multiple paths. I kind of concede that this might save a few bugs in future implementation, but just did not like to say that "the sequence number is per path". I use a paraphrase instead, stating that guarantee of increasing sequence is per path, which achieves the same goal but still allow implementation to have a single "send" counter for all paths if that save them some memory.

comments.body:
```suggestion
In addition to NO_ERROR(0x0) following {{QUIC-TRANSPORT}}, the following QUIC error codes are defined for use in the PATH_ABANDON frame.
```

While I agree that NO_ERROR is a fine error message for a PATH_ABANDON, the current text is not really clear about the other error codes defined in RFC9000. For instance, what should a receiver do if it receives a PATH_ABANDON with error code FLOW_CONTROL_ERROR? This would sound wrong to me, though it is not clear how a receiver would react.

I don't think the receiver would react it all. This is only for logging. If there are concerns about this that I think we would need to define a separate code space. Thinking more about this, I think using the QUIC error code space is wrong. I think we should not call this error code at all. In case of connection close, you actually close the connection because there was an unexpected protocol behavior. In case of the multipath extension, it is the same: if there is something unexpected, you have to close the whole connection. Therefore closing a path is never an error but always an explicit decision.
Yes, I agree with your point. If we need such logging, we may standardise a few PATH_ABANDON-specific reason code points (the three mentioned above seem sufficient).

As a reference, [HTTP/3's error code space](https://www.iana.org/assignments/http3-parameters/http3-parameters.xhtml#http3-parameters-error-codes) contains codes that cover various scenarios.

This include unexpected protocol errors, such as detecting the peer closed a stream it shouldn't and responding with a CONNECTION_CLOSE of H3_CLOSED_CRITICAL_STREAM.

But it also includes expected behaviours that are not errors, such as when an endpoint cancels a request (a bit like path abandon) by sending a REST_STREAM or STOP_SENDING using H3_REQUEST_CANCELLED.

In all these cases, an H3 implementation has space to ignore the specific language in the spec: use the wrong error code space (send a transport error when it was an application error), or send a generic code, or send an incorrect code. I don't think any of those cause any real problems for the recipient, as Mirja put it, it's mainly for debugging. And someone investigating these should always be skeptical of the peer not telling the ground truth.

On balance, I think its fine to use the QUIC error code space here. This is an example of an extension where we are building some more complexity into the transport and can expect to need to extend the shared codepoint space to suit.

I also think that using the QUIC error space is fine. It is fairly obvious that not all error codes defined in the QUIC error space apply to all scenarios. For example, a "transport parameter error" only makes sense when parsing transport parameters. The important property is that the error codes be unique.

I also do not think that any implementation should react to specific error code values, unless that's explicitly mentioned in the text of the standard. The purpose is documentation for helping debugging issues, or for passing information to the application and ultimately the user. We don't need a special registry for path abandon reasons.

What state are we speaking about? I think that we are saying either too much or too little. There many kinds of "states":

1) Lists of packets that were sent on the path and not yet acked by the peer,
2) Packets that were received from the peer and processed but not yet acked,
3) the total number of paths considered active, which some implementation use to decide when to increase the Max Path ID.

Suppose that an implementation has abandoned a path, had not received a Path Abandon from the peer, and is losing patience. It may do a number of things:

1) It may decide to drop any incoming packet on that path. That has no interoperability impact, as long as those dropped packets are never acknowledged. Indeed, that's exactly what would happen if the path had become bad and packets were dropped in the network. But it has some performance impact, since some packets will be in transit when the Path Abandon is sent. It is recommended to not do that earlier than 3 PTOs after sending the PATH_ABANDON frame.

2) It may decide to consider all packets send on that path as lost, and resend the frames through another path. That's fine. It might cause some duplicate transmission, but that also happens for other reasons (e.g., bad timers) and has no interoperability impact. The rules there are murky, because this is a tradeoff -- resend sooner minimizes the end-to-end latency caused by losses, but resend sooner also increases the risk of duplicate transmission, which reduces efficiency. The 3PTO rule is probably one end of the tradeoff: good mitigation of duplicate transmission, poor management of latency. A 1PTO rule would be a different tradeoff, more focused on managing latency.

3) It should send the "missing ACKs" on another path before clearing the missing ACK state. Again, that's an efficiency tradeoff. If the node does not send acknowledgements, it risks causing spurious retransmission. 

4) It may well decide to never increase the MAX_PATH_ID until the PATH_ABANDON has been received. That's a reasonable way for an implementation to conserve resource.

I would just say:

If a peer sends a PATH_ABANDON frame but never receives
a corresponding PATH_ABANDON frame, it might not be able to remove path state.
It is left to the implementation to handle this unexpected
behavior.

> 
> 1. Lists of packets that were sent on the path and not yet acked by the peer,
> 2. Packets that were received from the peer and processed but not yet acked,
> 3. the total number of paths considered active, which some implementation use to decide when to increase the Max Path ID.

Packet handling as mentioned in point 1 and 2 seems actually partly orthogonal here. If you have send the path abandon frame, you should probably not have any outstanding packets that need to be acked on that path. However, you should also never just forgot about outstanting/non-acked packets. If you decide to remove state about non-ack packets, you need to declare them lost and resent on another path. The important part is about packet handling of new incoming packets and you should be able to process those for at least 3 PTOs after sending the path abandon frame. This means, you need to remember the path ID and corresponding CID(s) as well as the packet number space state. However, as soon as you remove the CID(s), you cannot process any new incoming packets anymore and as such you can then also remove all packet number space state as well for received packets. The interesting case is actually your point 3. If you remove path state that means you remove the path ID and will consider it as not active anymore. As such you could send a new max path ID. It wants to say that ACK can be sent whatever the state of congestion control, but it says that by stating that "ACK packets do count as bytes in flight", which is wrong -- they create queues in the network just like other packets. comments.body: Typo. Should be " As packets that only carry", not "carries" (subject is plural).

@huitema You're right about the packets only contains ACK still create queues on switching devices and cause process cost on both sides. My suggestion is about that "PATH_ACK is not count into congestion control" isn't something new added by multipath extension, but is inherit from RFC 9000 and 9002.

```suggestion
and thus better performance. However, since packets that only carry PATH_ACK frames
```

Sec 7 of RFC9002 says:

"Similar to TCP, packets containing only ACK frames do not count toward bytes in flight and are not congestion controlled."

Further the next sentence in RFC9002 is actually:

"Unlike TCP, QUIC can detect the loss of these packets and MAY use that information to adjust the congestion controller or the rate of ACK-only packets being sent, but this document does not describe a mechanism for doing so."

Not really a comment on this PR, but the part about QUIC using acknowledgments of ACK packets may be a bit optimistic. ACK-only packets do not trigger ACK. Implementation may trigger that ACK by bundling a Ping with their ACK, but they cannot do that too frequently -- typically no more than once every N ACK, with N at least 2, and no more than once per RTT. So you get very scarce feedback, and any estimation of capacity based on that is imprecise. Plus, in the general case, the ACK traffic is way lower than link capacity, so you don't get an accurate estimate of capacity -- this is an app-limited scenario.

reviews.author: huitema
reviews.body: Looks good, but I wonder whether we are missing something. The discussion of congestion mentioned the risk to create a "thundering herd" if multiple connections use the same path as default, and the same other path as backup. No. The focus of the paragraph is on "address spoofing". The typical spoofed challenge / response scenario is:

1. Client sends PATH_CHALLENGE on tuple X
2. Server picks unique CID sends PATH_CHALLENGE + PATH_RESPONSE on symmetric of tuple X
3. Client does not reply because the source address was spoofed.
4. Server repeats PATH_CHALLENGE + PATH_RESPONSE a few time, subject to amplification limits.

Damage happens if the packet sent by the server is accepted and processed by the target because it somehow mimics a valid protocol.

This can be run in parallel for multiple tuples in both RFC9000 and multipath. In RFC9000, the protocol limit is the number of available CID at the server. With multipath, it is limited by the sum of CID available on all paths.

I wrote a small note on the subject of [multipath and congestion control](https://privateoctopus.com/2025/03/24/multipath-congestion-control.html). I do not think that RFC 9473 applies to scheduling algorithms. Scheduling algorithms define which packets goes on what path, and there are very many algorithms that could be tried, such as:

* associate QUIC streams to specific paths, so as to minimize the amount of reordering between packets received on the same path (some folks do that with picoquic)
* or, spread packets of a long stream on multiple paths, based on whichever path has congestion control credits available at time of scheduling (picoquic does that by default)
* or, send a stream twice, with one copy on each path, to get the best delivery delay,
* or, use some kind of FEC, send a stream on one path and redundant FEC packets on the other, to get the best delays without being too piggish.

All of those have been experimented. All depends on following whatever limits are imposed by per path congestion control.
